Yeah, I see that having two parallel “blog chains” is confusing, especially if the blog doesn’t really do a good job in presenting them differently. There’s so much I hate about the static website generators I’ve tried, but I felt I needed to get started with publishing and fix all that template stuff later. 

So there’s “Universal Structure”, which is about what I learned from cognitive science and I believe is valuable for programming and there’s “Beyond Code”, which is more solution-oriented and my take on what I’d like to build (without necessarily having that figured out fully yet).

I really want to have categories for each series and index pages to make that all easier to navigate but that means I have to find another theme or fix the one I’m using right now, and that’s just distracting me from writing.

text: *Native > Web* My main point of disagreement is on this one. For me the web is the plate-form to use because of its very special nature. It is based on standards that are everywhere and are here to stay independently of any other considerations. Of course they have drawbacks and add some layers of abstraction that can be seen as non necessary, but their advantages are more important for me. I have already developped this point some time ago on this Slack, for me anything to do now about Future of Programming has to be build on top of the web plate-form.

Inertia is a powerful force. Popularity also means folks have used it in all kinds of use cases and you're likely to find libraries an integrations with everything else out there.

I use Python a lot and the multithreading solution seems like overkill for this problem. BTW you can actually write the multiline literal with `\` in Python like so: `r'''hello \ hello'''`.  Looks like Beads has some kind of built in loop timer (loom_timer)? Maybe writing this in pygame would get closer to what Beads does.

If we think of subsuming the existing languages rather than replacing them, I think we have a better chance of something new catching on. What I mean is instead of providing a just a language - you provide a larger system that integrates other features such as a distributed database. This creates the other concern here that this becomes a 'misfit' in the current ecosystem, however if the value proposition is large I think folks will actually start using it. Of the listed features of Beads, the most interesting to me are the graph database and reversible debugging. Would love to see how this works. These are hard to show in comparison of text programs snippets though.

text:
Javascript was a mandated monopoly; Java had huge backing from Sun Microsystems. Python has steadily grown without a corporate sponsor purely on merit i believe. It's significant indenting syntax saves about 13% character count, which is why i adopted it in Beads. I understand it has benefited greatly recently due to the massive popularity of ML tools like TensorFlow which revolve around Python.

The existing languages need to be replaced for the simple reason their computational model is archaic. Wedded deeply to the asymmetries and imperfections of the Intel and ARM instruction sets which together control 99% of all computers sold today. If you look at Excel, it offers a completely different virtual machine than Intel. It offers sparse matrices, protected arithmetic, and easy layout (provided it fits a grid structure).  Excel also have sophisticated computational support for things like backsolving (although hardly any users know to use to this feature). I feel the battle is one to supplant both Excel and the top 3 languages, in one tool that finally bridges these two almost uncommunicating realms.

text:
<@UJ6LDMMN0> Thanks for your kind feedback and the tweet! You bring up some excellent points:

In short, I think the whole last section about technology choices is mostly just stating my personal preferences which have more to do with my past experience than anything else. I consider them a lot less important (that’s why they go last) and I don’t think they have much impact on inventing a future of programming in general. They mostly have an impact on my own work, because if I chose technologies I don’t like or don’t know well enough, I’m just not setting myself up for success.

In other words, if your background and your heart is in web technologies, than you should absolutely pick that as the foundation for your projects.

The mobile over desktop thing I feel strongly about because I’d like to “skate to where the puck will be”, and I just don’t believe that everyday computing will happen much longer on a classic mouse + keyboard interface. It’ll still be around for decades mostly for us who have issues with leaving text editors and terminal emulations behind, and I don’t really have a problem with that. I don’t even think touchscreens are where it’s at and we’ll be soon entering the AR age, whatever that means. Most (non-programming) people have most of their computational needs being met on a smartphone today, and if I want to reach those people, I need to start where they are. I could be wrong, of course. But I’d like to take that bet.

On collaboration I have much more to say. But not now. And I will likely do that in a future blog post. I can tell you that there was a paragraph “collaboration” in all drafts and edits until I published it.

text:
<@UE6EFEPTQ> Ok, so my approach is kind of the opposite to “general first and see how it goes”, because I think starting with a goal of building something generic (as in Turing-complete) puts you directly into programming language land. Nothing wrong with that! But everybody is doing that already.

I like to look at large, creative applications for music production, video editing, or visual design as examples for creative tools that enable people to create quite a large variety of creative content. These tools might have grown surprisingly or accidentally or even intentionally turing-complete over time (see <<https://www.gwern.net/Turing-complete|https://www.gwern.net/Turing-complete>> for context), but they started out with a focus of how to manipulate domain-specific data structures visually. That’s what I find interesting and promising. I’m not opposed to ending up with something generic and powerful and Turing-complete, but I’d like to get there organically and not mandate it from the start.

I also feel like setting it as a goal from the beginning frames the whole problem as “just” inventing another (visual?) programming language — and I find that limiting.

When you ask about DSL, did it even occur to you that I might not even look for a language? Most of us here would probably expect something language-like to come out of that process. But I don’t know really, what I’m looking for yet. I’m more looking into data structures and what the essence of structure is and how much more those domain-specific data structures mentioned above can be generalized.

I know that this sounds weird, and frankly probably not very promising, perhaps esoteric. Hence my attempts to explain where I’m coming from in these blog posts. I hope I can get everyone who’s interested enough to a place where they no longer think it’s weird, and then we can start discussing how promising it is.
